text: 1. He who knows the oldest and the best becomes himself the oldest and the best. Breath indeed is the oldest and the best.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. He who knows the richest, becomes himself the richest. Speech indeed is the richest.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. He who knows the firm rest, becomes himself firm in this world and in the next. The eye indeed is the firm rest.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. He who knows success, his wishes succeed, both his divine and human wishes. The ear indeed is success.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. He who knows the home, becomes a home of his people. The mind indeed is the home.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. The five senses quarrelled together 2 , who was the best, saying, I am better, I am better.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. They went to their father Pra g âpati and said: 'Sir, who is the best of us?' He replied: 'He by whose departure the body seems worse than worst, he is the best of you.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 8. The tongue (speech) departed, and having been absent for a year, it came round and said: 'How have you been able to live without me?' They replied: 'Like mute people, not speaking, but breathing with the breath, seeing with the eye, hearing with the ear, thinking with the mind. Thus we lived.' Then speech went back.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 9. The eye (sight) departed, and having been absent for a year, it came round and said: 'How have you been able to live without me?' They replied: 'Like blind people, not seeing, but breathing with the breath, speaking with the tongue, hearing with the ear, thinking with the mind. Thus we lived.' Then the eye went back.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 10. The ear (hearing) departed, and having been absent for a year, it came round and said: 'How have you been able to live without me?' They replied: 'Like deaf people, not hearing, but breathing with the breath, speaking with the tongue, thinking with the mind. Thus we lived.' Then the ear went back.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 11. The mind departed, and having been absent for a year, it came round and said: 'How have you been able to live without me?' They replied: 'Like children whose mind is not yet formed, but breathing with the breath, speaking with the tongue, seeing with the eye, hearing with the ear. Thus we lived.' Then the mind went back.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 12. The breath, when on the point of departing, tore up the other senses, as a horse, going to start,

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: might tear up the pegs to which he is tethered 1 . They came to him and said: 'Sir, be thou (our lord); thou art the best among us. Do not depart from us!'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 13. Then the tongue said to him: 'If I am the richest, thou art the richest.' The eye said to him: 'If I am the firm rest, thou art the firm rest 2 .'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 14. The ear said to him: 'If I am success, thou art success.' The mind said to him: 'If I am the home, thou art the home.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 15. And people do not call them, the tongues, the eyes, the ears, the minds, but the breaths (prâ n a, the senses). For breath are all these.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 72:1 The chief object is to show the different ways on which people proceed after death. One of these ways, the Devapatha that leads to Brahman and from which there is no return, has been described, IV, 15. The other ways for those who on earth know the conditioned Brahman only, have to be discussed now.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 72:2 The same fable, the prâ n asa m vâda or prâ n avidyâ, is told in the B ri hadâra n yaka VI, 1, 1-14, the Aitareya Âr. II, 4, the Kaush. Up. III, 3, and the Pra s na Up. II, 3. The last is the simplest version of all, but it does not follow therefore that it is the oldest. It would be difficult to find two fables apparently more alike, yet in reality differing from each other more characteristically than this fable and the fable told to the plebeians by Menenius Agrippa.
